instruction: What metric was chosen for the detection of citrus canker in laboratory conditions and verified in the grove?
Output: The metric (vegetation indices) chosen for the detection of canker in laboratory conditions was the water index (WI), and it achieved a high accuracy in detecting canker. In orchard conditions, the Modified Chlorophyll Absorption in Reflectance Index (ARI and TCARI 1) was chosen as the metric, and it also accurately detected canker.

instruction: What were the results of using the radial basis function (RBF) and K nearest neighbor (KNN) classification methods in detecting citrus canker in laboratory conditions and in the field using an unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV)?
Output:
The results of using the radial basis function (RBF) and K nearest neighbor (KNN) classification methods in detecting citrus canker were as follows:

In laboratory conditions:
- RBF method achieved higher overall classification accuracy (94%, 96%, and 100%) for detecting canker in leaves compared to the KNN method (94%, 95%, and 96%).
- Among the 31 studied vegetation indices, the water index (WI) more accurately detected canker in laboratory conditions.

In the field using an unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV):
- The same imaging system mounted on a UAV was used to detect citrus canker on tree canopies in the orchard.
- The RBF method achieved 100% classification accuracy for identifying healthy and canker-infected trees.
